376. Nu-zuk. verb, to be White, Bright, or Shining. (may also be written nu-zuk or nutzuk). This is the Syriac ναπ ἑλίσσεται. The derived adjective ναπ ἀυγαῖος means (1) purus, (2) λαμπτός, splendens, albicans, ex gr. as an epithet of a star: or of pellucid sparkling water: or of white linen or byssus. Castelli 563. Schaaf's lex. gives a similar account of the word.

Hence, precious stones in general are called Nisikti stones in Assyrian, see my No. 170, corrected by No. 250. Nisikta occurs in Syriac as a fem. plural Ἑλίσσω, see Schaaf p. 357.

Examples of the verb nuzuk. Tig. vii, 95 describes the building of a Bit illat or 'apartment of splendour' of which the internal walls "mahatish nutsuku, were very bright or glistening—by the effect of the sculptor's chisel." They were therefore probably of white marble.

In R 7 E we find: Shalu-su nutsuku, 'its powder was shining white' (see these passages more fully given in Nos. 371 and 375).

Another interesting example of the word is found in B.M. 40, 5, where Sennacherib says 'I made shallat ruzati (bas reliefs) of the stone called itsir rabu —ανάλημνα "sha zimi nutsuku kima tami, 'of which the broken pieces, or chips, were white and glistening like the day (or sky)', .......... kilallan in shaddi-sun aduk, ana sipri hekali-ya usalida kireb ir Niná, 'all of them I sculptured in their own mountains, and for the embellishment of my palace I had them carried to Niniveh'.—It is evident how close this statement is to that in R 7 E quoted in No. 375; extending even to the fact that Sennacherib had the slabs of stone sculptured on the spot where they were quarried.
in the mountains, (probably those of Nypur); and to the remarkable whiteness of the chips or fragments. The two passages therefore confirm and explain each other. The *itsir rabu* may be 'white marble,' for two reasons, first because the name seems cognate with the verb *usatsir* which is always employed in the sense of skilful or artistic work, and is a causative conjugation of the Heb. finxit, formavit; secondly because of its having bright white fragments, a character which few other stones possess.

*Zimi* Chald. rejectamenta here probably 'chips' or 'fragments' left by the sculptors. *Abduk*, from the verb *patak* or *pitik* 'to sculpture,' which occurs very frequently. This word has been skilfully restored by Mr. Norris p. 848.

377. *Naru.* , a Tablet, usually made of stone. This word is seldom employed; the usual term for a stone tablet being the Accadian of which the pronunciation is uncertain. But the word *Naru* is used on some of the Michaux stones, and in the tablet K 240, which contains an instructive list of words synonymous with 'a tablet.' We find, besides , , , , and , ; Sikkatu and Masuktu (which two last appear related to each other). Also two curious words denoting a sepulchral stone or monument, , , Abna abi bani 'monument of a Father,' and , , Abna makhritu 'monument of the departed.' This word makhritu is often used in Assyrian for 'the late,' 'the deceased,' just as the Greeks use ὁ μακαρίτης in speaking of a person very recently dead. Indeed I think the Greek word is borrowed from the Assyrian, although the Greeks themselves doubtless assimilated it to their own language, and derived it from μακάριος 'blessed'. This tablet gives some other synonyms for a 'monumental stone' viz., , erimmatu (this may possibly be Heb. 'a heap or mound,' which is the Eppa of the Greeks). Also, Kapirru Heb. 'sepulcrum'; Matsabu Heb. matsaba
'cippest,' a sepulchral monument; and finally, ア叙述 Anatu, which may mean 'stone of sorrow' or 'sorrowful memorial,' from Heb. נִ֤ים to mourn or lament.

¶ Examples of the P.C., or Accadian word Tig. viii, 68. Sha bit-ellan ashar la mari pisirish inakimu, 'he who shall hide my tablets contemptuously in some back building, in a place where they cannot be seen'—

illan 'behind.' Pisirish from Ch. and Syr. אֱלֹהְּנּוֹ supsavit, contempsit, neglexit—Inakimu 'shall hide,' from nakam; (hence Bit nakimmat, or nakamti, a room shut up; a treasury).

The following example is found in 1 Mich. iv, 21 (R pl. 70), 'May the great gods whose names are written in this tablet, curse him with a curse which cannot be removed!' Ili rabî, mala in nari anni mu-sun zakru, arrat la napsuri liruru su!

Mala 'whosoever.' Zakru 'are written;' from יַע in Assyrian 'to write,' but in Hebrew 'to record.' Nari is substituted in 3 Mich. for in this passage.

¶ It is uncertain how the word was pronounced, but probably Nadâ. For one of the values of is da (see Norris p. vii and p. 268, quoting Sard. i, 25 darîsh 'for ever.') Moreover in tablet K 240, already mentioned, next to Nadâ, stands Nadâ; and

° ن س م ن ع ي ر ل ت ن y Constr. 4 Nuru. (ن س م ن ع ي ر ل ت ن y or ن س م ن ع ي ر ل ت ن y a Tablet. (seemingly a variation of the last word).—Tig. vi, 15 describes how the city of Khunutsa was taken and destroyed. The whole city was burnt. The Citadel with its three great towers of brick was thrown down, burnt, and reduced to ruins and rubbish. The very site of the city was obliterated, by heaps of stones thrown over it. The account then continues as follows : Nuru takabar ebus, kisiti mati sha in Ya bil-ya aksudu. Ir suatu ana la zabati, u Dur-su la razapi in eli althur: bit sha agamri in eli-su urzip, naru takabar sa-atun in libbi usasi'b—'I made tablets
of bronze, obtained in the lands which in the name of Jah my lord I had conquered. I displayed upon them that city [Khunutsa] as it was before it was taken; and its Citadel, as it was before it was burnt. Then I erected a building of brick, and those tablets of bronze I placed therein. In this passage Razapi, is the Chald. 'to burn;' subst. 'coals of fire.'

Another example is found in Opp. Khors. line 135—Nuru ekili-sun, sha ultu tami ulluti in isiti mitti Zuti ekimû, ramanasssun utirru; 'the tablets [i.e. landmarks] of their fields, which a long while ago from many estates the Zuti had carried off, I restored to themselves [i.e. the right owners]. These Nuru or landmarks were a sort of title deeds, showing to every passer by to what family a field belonged. The Zuti appear to have been a tribe of savage warriors, allies of Merodach Baladan. They were all put to death by Sargina. Isiti estates, holdings, possessions; from isa to have or possess. Ekimû, observe the lengthened vowel which marks the pluperfect tense, 'they had seized (a long time ago). So in the first example of this article, aksud is 'I acquired or took,' but aksudu (pluperf.) 'I had acquired' (some time before).

379. Liki. verb 'to Receive.' Heb. לִקְיָה 'cepit, accepit,' etiam 'cepit auribus; percepit.' Greek λαχω. In 2 R 66, 7 the goddess Beltis has the following epithets: Samat ikribi, likat unnini; 'She who hears our prayers, and receives our supplications.' Here is the feminine participle. This example is fully confirmed by another taken from the tablet 120 otherwise 89b where Ashurbanipal addresses Marduk . Liki unnini-ya. Simi kala-ya; Receive my prayers! Hear my voice!

Simi is the Heb. שִׁמְיָה 'to hear:' its participle feminine is samat 'she who hears,' auditrix (see the first example)—Kala 'voice' is evidently the Chald. קַלְה Heb. קַלְה 'voice.' I do not recollect however to have met the word elsewhere.
380. Zitta. Oil. (Lat. Oleum. Oliva). Heb. Zit Syr. Zita, and the same in all the Semitic languages. I have only found the word hitherto in the name of the city Bit-Zitta, 'the City of Olives' which is mentioned as one of those captured by Sennacherib on the seacoast of Palestine R 38, 39.

381. Suman or Summanu. Butter. The same with the Chald. Butyrum; Arab. سمن and سماعن (Schindler). This appears to me to be the meaning of the gloss in 2 R 7, 29 سماعن شا غا, 'butter of the Cow.' All this column consists of words beginning with SM therefore I read sumannu or summanu. سماعن is a term for unctuous substances in general, as grease, fat, oil, unguent, &c. Hence for distinction's sake the Arabic expresses 'butter' by سماعن بكري 'butyrum de vaccâ.' (Sch.)

382. Bara. adj. Fat. Heb. pinguis, ex gr. decem boves pingues 1 Kings iv, 23. But the word may equally well be read מרא (which Norris prefers, p. 847) for, the Hebrew is also written מירא, which is a good example of the connexion between the letters B and M.

Phill. i, 16. Sha tamu I ga makhi bara. 'Every day one ox, large and fat, and one other ox (&c. &c.) I allotted to the gods of Babylon as their portion.' This has much resemblance to what we read in 1 Kings iv, 23—'Solomon's provision for one day was ten fat oxen and twenty other oxen,' (&c. &c.)

383. Pattaruna. adj. Fat. Agrees well with the Heb. Padar 'fat;' the final N augmenting the meaning, as in many other words.

Esar. iii, 59. Ga makkhi pattaruna, 'oxen large and fat.' This was part of the tribute of Bel-basa king of Gambuli, whom Esarhaddon thereupon confirmed in his kingdom, and having made his capital city Shapi-Bel into a strong fortress, commissioned him to watch the frontier of Elam.

384. Paklut. adj. Fat.

Ga makhe pakluti, 'oxen large and fat' Phill. iii, 9. I know not whether the Greek παχύς is related.
385. **La**. **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ a Bull or Ox.—2 R 25, 7 explains La by **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ Allou ‘bull’ Heb. אָרֶץ (Gloss. No. 298). Also I find on a tablet the Accadian Ga kim ‘like a bull’ rendered by the Assyrian kinu Lie. Moreover the sacred images of bulls are often called **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ כְּדֵי Lu shaddi. And see Norris p. 855 where they are called in one copy Lu shaddi and in the other **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ כְּדֵי. This last is explained by **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ shaedu (good spirit or genius) in Norris p. 32. Hence I think that lu shaddi is but another form of lu shaedi divine bulla.

386. **Suru.** **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ a Bull. Agrees with the Heb. **אֲלֹהִים** Sur ‘a bull.’ In 2 R 25, 8 we find the explanation **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ כְּדֵי i.e. Suru means Albu (a bull).

Another example, from Sen. T. v, 74. (Norris p. 867) Kima suri maruti ‘like fattened oxen’ **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ כְּדֵי אֲלֹהִים אָרֶץ כְּדֵי. This occurs in the account of the battle of Khaluli. The Chiefs of the Enemy, wearing collars of gold and swords with golden sheaths, appeared to Sennacherib an easy prey, and a tempting booty, just as the capture might be of a herd of fat beoves, offering no resistance.

387. **Kurutz.** **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ כְּדֵי A piece cut off—a joint—a morsel. Exactly the Chald. **אֲלֹהִים** kurutz ‘frustum’: which occurs in Daniel iii, 8 and vi, 25 **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ comedit frusta (Ges.): and the same phrase is found in Syriac.

Nibritu izbat-zunuti. Ana buri-sun seri abli-sun binti-sun ekilu, ikzutzu kurutzu. A Famine seized them. For food they ate the limbs of their sons and daughters, and cut them up into morsels. Smith’s Assurbanipal* p. 163. Ikzutzu is from the Heb. **אֲלֹהִים** amputavit, abscedit, dissecut.

388. **Buru.** **אֲלֹהִים** אָרֶץ Food. Heb. **אֲלֹהִים** ‘cibus,’ from **אֲלֹהִים** ‘comedit,’ er. gr. **אֲלֹהִים** ‘to eat bread.’ Gesenius thinks this Hebrew word cognate with Bopa and vorare. Add the Germ. Brad, which closely resembles **אֲלֹהִים**, and the Welsh Bara ‘bread.’ An example of the word Buru will be found in

the last article. Another occurs in Smith's Assurbanipal p. 193 in the narrative of a shipwreck, ana buri-sun, 'for their food' [the following words are lost].

389. Lu, a Table. Heb. Luh Tabula. Lu as libbi ekulu ishtu, the table at which he used to eat and drink. Assur. p. 227.

390. Maskita. Wine mixed with Spices. In Hebrew Psalm 75, 9—Gesenius says 'vinum mixtum, i.e. aromatibus.'—See also Proverbs ix, 2. Isaiah v, 22. Kurun maskita sha Sar: spiced wine for the king. 2 R 44, 10.

391. Kurun. Wine. Often replaced by the monogram . Seems related to the Heb. a Vine, or Vineyard.

Akul akalu, siti kurunnu! eat food, drink wine! Assur. 125 translated by Mr. G. Smith. In R 7 No. ix A the king is represented pouring a libation upon four dead lions before an altar and the inscription says: Kurun akká eli-sun, I poured a libation of wine upon them. Kurun is written , akká from the Heb. 'libavit.'— water and wine' 2 R 44, 8; opposite which is written which may be kasim 'goblets' Heb.—Same page l. 13 followed by kharrubu, may be flasks or skins of wine. Ch. uter, lagena vini.

The sign for 'wood' or 'vegetable' is sometimes prefixed ex gr. Oppert's Sargon folio p. 16 in the description of a famine. "The poor people could get no food: Ina zabal karani akula ana khareu, with the skins (or dregs) of grapes (they found) food for their bellies." refuse; food; belly. I have supplied the letter which seems wanting after akula. But the meaning of the passage and even its reading, is uncertain.

Sometimes are tangled creepers Anglicè Bines, F. Lianes.—See Assur. 267 in the account of Assurbanipal's army struggling through a forest, and impeded by
perhaps thorns or brambles for I find in 2 R 45, 59. this word, or 
which is equivalent to it (putting the Accadian plural ra instead of the Assyrian) explained by akhartannu or akhartan probably 'thorns' from the Syriac a sharp point, and when used as a verb 'to pierce.'

In Bavian 19 we read that Sennacherib planted near Niniveh Woods and Vineyards.

The monogram is explained karana in 2 R 45, 58 and also in Syl. 173.

392. Azzari. a Bird. This is the same as izzuri 'a bird' (Gloss. No. 10): but so distinct a form deserves to be mentioned. Kima azzari edish ipparesid, like a bird he fled away alone. R 39, 48.

393. Atalu. an Eclipse. Syriac shadow. In 3 R 58 No. 8 l. ult. the usual symbol for an eclipse (divine darkness) is explained by the gloss Atalu.

394. Mi. Night. Five days and nights—3 R 12, slab ii, 30. Day and night. 2 R 32, 4. See more examples under Zalmu No. 396 and Mi No. 268.

395. Takhatu. Night. (see Gloss. No. 26.) Another example of this word is found in 3 R 55, 50 "Offer a sacrifice (likruth) to the god Yem and Ishtar in the night time, as takhati.—In 3 R 66 Yom, Ishtar, and other gods are sacrificed to by starlight, (reverse col. 1, 13) and by moonlight (obverse col. 5, 25).

396. Zalmu. Darkness. This is exactly the Arabic zalm 'dark' otherwise zalām (in Catafago p. 433).—In 3 R 59, No. 7 and No. 9 (darkness) is twice explained by zalmu, and in 2 R 49, 42 by zalmi. The Hebrew equivalent is 'umbra' Psalm xxxix, 7 (the original root is)—(Gesenius says that imago is the same word; because an imago is the σκια of the object.

In 2 R 37, 30 a bird (probably the Owl) is called Itsur musi

(bird of night) and also zulamu, and zalamdu. These two words are evidently derived from zalam or zalmu darkness.

397. Kil. Sand. See the account of the shipwreck of Tammaritu king of Elam in Assur. p. 192. "The ship of Tammaritu was caught by a terrible tempest. The steersman of the ship leaped from the ship upon the sand. Tammaritu following after him was thrown, on the dangerous rocky ground, and very much injured."

The last two clauses stand thus in the original. Sikudi abati the steersman of the ship, sul leaped, ultu kireb elip suatu from out of that ship, ana kili upon the sand. Tammaritu ana arka su after him, issi was thrown. Marustu haggar namratsi the dangerous stony ground, uparriru's much wounded him.

Here we have sikudi 'the watchman' from Heb. to watch or keep guard. I translate it however 'the steersman,' according to the lines of Æschylus (Sept. c. Theb. l. 3) Οἰάκα νομων—βλεφαρα μη κοιμων ὑπνω 'the ever-watching or ever-watchful steersman'—abati 'the ship.' This is a most interesting word, because it occurs once, and once only, in the Old Testament, being in all probability the of Job ix, 26 where the commentators disagree exceedingly as to its meaning (except that it is a ship of some kind). It is therefore very satisfactory to find it in Assyrian.

Sul 'he leaped' is the Ch. and Syr. 'cum impetu cucurrit.' Kilu 'the sand' agrees entirely with the Chald. and Heb. 'arena in litore maris.'

398. Urku, a Dog. Some further examples may be added to those contained in No. 369. Assur. p. 166 "I caused their flesh to be eaten by dogs, usakil kalbi (or urki)—Usakil is the S conjugation of akal 'to eat' Heb. Again in the next page 'I threw their bodies as food to the dogs' rihit kalbi (or urki). Rihit 'food' from Heb. to feed.

In 2 R 42, 67 there is a gloss which identifies the meaning of urku with the Heb. kaleb. For, is there
explained by lishan kalbi the tongue of a dog. In the preceding line the Accadian voice or mouth, takes the place of lishan. Moreover, if we can trust these glosses, one of the synonyms of Urku was Tsir. This, if true, is curious, because I have shown in Art. No. 108 of this glossary that the Assyrian mythology possessed (no doubt in Hades) a seven-headed monster called a Tsir, and therefore it was probably a seven-headed dog, a sort of Cerberus.

In 3 R 65, No. 2 reverse, urmakh and urku (lion and dog) are repeatedly mentioned together. This tablet relates dreams of some portentous births; such as (1) having the head of a lion or dog (2) altogether like a lion or dog (kilullan kima like, urmakh a lion).

In tablet K 217 there is a list of urku ‘dogs’ and ur shal which I suppose means ‘female dogs,’ but this is uncertain.

399. Kun. otherwise a Tail. 2 R 34, 21

Kun sha kalbi, ‘tail of a dog,’

Kunut-zun ‘their tails’ occurs in the tablet about dogs and lions 3 R 65 No. 2 reverse line 64, which also speaks of ‘their heads,’ ‘their faces,’ &c. &c.

I have already noticed in a former article, that in the dog tablet K 236 kunut-zun ‘their tails’ occurs twice, written and the passage in the hunting scene, Urmakh as kun azbat “I seized the Lion by his tail,” where the sculpture confirms the inscription.

I will add a very different example of the word, viz. the Assyrian description of a Comet. “Star which has before it a corona or glory (tsipra Heb. ‘corona caput ambiens’) and behind it a tail.” 3 R 52, 55, this curious passage has been noted by Sir H. Rawlinson and Mr. G. Smith. The original words are Kakkab sha as pan-su tsipra, as arka-su kun.

In 2 R 20, 41 we find Nuzur sha kun, which apparently means ‘wagging the tail’ from Hebrew.
400. **Khuraza.** 金 Gold. Heb. זהב. A different spelling of the word has been given already in No. 29.

(金) is translated on a tablet Khuraza russá.

401. **Anak.** Lead. Agrees exactly with the Heb. Anak 铅 plumbum. In an "Ode to Fire" I find: "Thou, O Fire, art the melter of bronze and lead." Sha eri u anaki mubullil-sun atta! Written 金 and 金. Mubullil is the participle of bullul to melt, Heb 金 fudit.

402. **Anna.** 银 Lead. This is the Accadian word which translates the Assyrian Anak in the preceding passage. It occurs very frequently, even in Assyrian writings, while Anak is seldom found.

403. **Nazir.** 金 a Royal Crown. Agrees exactly with the Heb. נזר which Gesenius renders Diadema: specialiter regis. I find on a tablet nazir rabu rendered in Accadian 金 mir rabu, which means as we know 'a great crown,' see the art. Mir No. 156. It is added that this nazir was worn 'on his head,' as risi-su 金 I.

Saul wore his nazir on his head in battle. 2 Sam. i, 10.

404. **Amia.** 金 a Crown (in Accadian). In 2 R 24, 60 and also 32, 13 we have 金 rendered by the Assyrian 金 Agú, 'a crown.' And on the tablets amia-kim is frequently rendered kima agie, 金 being the plural of Agú.

405. **Karpa.** 金 a water-vessel or flaggon. Same as the Syriac garba 金 Chald. 金 uter, lagena, hydria. Compare also the Greek Καλπής used by Homer and Pindar for a water-vessel or pitcher. The Accadian word corresponding is 金 Duk, perhaps connected with the Greek Τευχός a vessel or urn.

Mie sunuti ana karpati tar-ma, return those waters into the pitcher! (Tablet.)

And I find among the curses, two consecutive lines: "May they pour him out like water: may they break him like the pitcher!" The Accadian words are 金 A-kim, and 金 Duk-kim; the Assyrian kima mie and kima karpati.
But the word 𒂗𒂗 or karpa is sometimes used for a very costly vessel, apparently one employed in the Mysteries, as in the following two lines, of which the first only has been published by Mr. G. Smith in his Assurbanipal, p. 332.

As passuri illiti, akalu illiti akul!
As karpati 𒂗𒂗 illiti, mie illiti siti!
Eat the precious food, out of a precious dish!
Drink the precious drink, out of a precious vessel!

An epithet 𒂗𒂗 whose meaning is at present unknown, is here given to the vessel.

406. Immiri. 𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 Sheep or Lambs. Chald. 𒂗𒂗 Agnus; which makes in the plural 𒂗𒂗. I think there can be no doubt of this word. An Accadian tablet has, in two consecutive lines,

Ga kim 'like oxen': translated kima Alpi.
Lu kim 'like sheep': translated kima Immiri.

Some have rendered Immiri by 'asses,' supposing it to be the Heb. ��, but this is quite unsuitable. In Phill. iii, 12, 'fat oxen' are sacrificed, and immediately afterwards immir gukallam, probably 'fat sheep.' So also in 2 R 38, 30 kubú alpi 'a drove of oxen' stands next to kubú imiri 'a flock of sheep.'

The following is another example of the word. Kima immiri itbukh-su, 'it slays him like a sheep.' The verb 𒂗𒂗 itbukh is the Heb. תַּבְעֵה 'mactavit pecudem.'

407. Suhi. 𒂗𒂗 Lambs. Heb. שׁוֹי ovis, vel agnus. In Opp. Khors. 19 l. ult. suhi maruti (fat lambs) are offered to the gods at a festival, along with ga makhi bitruti (fattened oxon).

408. Huk. 𒂗𒂗 a Flock. 2 R 38, 26 where it is explained by 𒂗𒂗 Kalú a drove or flock. The word is commonly written 𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 as in my art. 304, but I now think this is a compound word, 𒂗𒂗 'flock,' 𒂗𒂗 'sheep,' 𒂗𒂗 'many':—'Large flocks of sheep.'
409. **Maruti.** Fat. Heb. pinguis, saginatus. *Suhî maruti* 'fat lambs'; *Suri maruti* 'fat oxen.' Sen. T. v. 74. Layard's Inscriptions, 34, 1.

410. **Bitruti.** Fat. *Ga makkhi bitruti*, fine fat oxen. XVI pasilli bitruti, sixteen fat (…) Phill. ii, 27, and Opp. Khors. 19 l. ult. These were offered in the temple every day.

411. **Dussuti.** Fat. Probably from the Hebrew יָעֵן to be fat. *dussuti* … lu-akki, fat sheep I sacrificed. Bavian 33, quoted by Norris Dict. p. 639.

412. **Bunnanni.** Statues. A very common word, used in such phrases as "Whoever destroys my bunnanni, let him be accursed!" The meaning is ascertained by a tablet, which translates bunnanni and zalam by the same word. The latter is the Heb. מַלְאָה a statue.

413. **Ekal**, or **Hekal.** a Palace: the Hebrew דֶּרֶךְ. This word is very seldom found phonetically written: it is generally expressed by אֲדֹנִי אֲדֹנִי which means 'the Great House.' In Assyrian this would sound Bit Rab, but in Accadian He-kal, from He 'house' and Kal or Gal 'great.' In ancient Egyptian also He signified 'a house.' The Turkish family of languages in general have Hu. Hence we see that the cuneiform texts give us a clear and simple etymology of the Hebrew דֶּרֶךְ, respecting which there is nothing satisfactory in the lexicons.

Example: אֲדֹנִי אֲדֹנִי אֲדֹנִי this means "at the gate of the temple"; and immediately afterwards it is phonetically written אֲדֹנִי אֲדֹנִי אֲדֹנִי as bab Ekalli.

414. **Bu.** the Mouth. This word is given by Norris (Dict. p. 63) quoting 39 II where it is explained by the Accadian Ka 'the mouth' a very common word. He adds that it is the Heb. בְּעֵן the mouth. But as he adduces no example I will give one from a tablet, which says of the waters of the Euphrates Bu illu sha Bit-a ullil sunuti, "the grand mouth of
Kakku, or Kak. 

A sword. Perhaps connected with the Heb. root כָּהֵם 'to cut.' Occurs rather frequently. Expressed in Assyrian by כָּהֵם (see my No. 392). But since the sign כָּהֵם determinative of wooden objects seems unsuitable, I conjecture that כָּהֵם is a very ancient
corruption of the Accadian kak obtained by removing the vertical wedge a little towards the right hand. Example: "The god (....) lord of the sword, will never give him his sword of strength, upon the battle field." This stands thus in Assyrian: Bil kakki kak dannuti-su ai ittan-su ashar gibli u takhzi. The Accadian has 'Lord of the sword,' and 'his strong sword.'

417. Kakkab. a Star. Agrees exactly with the Heb. Examples: as kakkab shamami val utaddu "to the stars of heaven he paid no attention" (or did not observe them). The Accadian version has 'stars' 'of heaven.' Again: kima kakkab shamami 'like the stars of heaven': where the Accadian renders 'heaven' by simply.

I have already given the adverb kakkabish shamami 'like the stars of heaven' see No. 246. Its spelling is

418. Kakkad. the Head. I find this to be a very frequent word. It seems an abbreviation of the old Hebrew Kadkad 'the head.' I formerly read Hakkad (see No. 108) but I have now adopted the pronunciation given by Oppert and others. Occasionally I find kaksu written for kakkadu, which may be only a more rapid pronunciation.

The three last words together with Kaggar 'the Earth' (see No. 109) comprise all the substantives at present known to me which begin with the syllable kak.

419. Nin. a Lord. In 2 R 58, 56 the god Héa (or Bita) is called the Nin (or Lord) of the Bright Face (or Bright Eye). Nin being written in Col. 1, but in Col. 2.

420. Nini. This is explained by Ili (gods) in Syllab. 688. It therefore seems to be properly the plural of the preceding word Nin (No. 419). I have found some
A GLOSSARY OF THE

examples of its actual usage. In 2 R 59, 14 a goddess is called
\[ \text{bilat 'qeer, } \text{niini (of the gods).} \] In 2 R 59, 14
we find \[ \text{bilat 'qeer, ili (of the gods).} \] It
is evident that the niini of the first passage are the ili of the
second. But in the following passage \[ \text{niini} \] is singular and
means Nin (a Lord): "The god Y-a \[ \text{niini} \] raba (great lord)
of heaven and earth." 3 R 44, col. 4, 3.

421. Nin. \[ \text{niini} \] a Lady. Written the same as Nin (a Lord) but
may have been pronounced somewhat differently. Occurs very
frequently. It is often put in opposition to \[ \text{bil} \] Bil (Dominus).
Thus, in Art. No. 367 I have mentioned the Bil and Nin (god and
goddess) of knowledge; and the Bil and Nin of \[ \text{niini} \] who are found on the photograph of tablet K 48. But on some
of the tablets are longer lists of deities, given in pairs, the Bil and
the Nin of each kind.

\[ \text{niini} \] or Nin also means a Wife. Ex. gr. Tarku king of Egypt
died. Arkina Urdmani tar nin-na as guzu-su usib: "afterwards
Urdmani the son of his wife sat upon his throne" (Smith's
Assurbanipal p. 47).

\[ \text{niini} \] or Nin is sometimes 'a Woman,' ex. gr. Nin khisakkti
hekali-m malabusa: all the favourite women of his palace (ibid.
p. 200).

Nin, as I have said, means both Lord and Lady. The same
ambiguity of meaning is found in the word \[ \text{dam} \] Dam 'conjux'
which is used both for husband and wife [see No. 423]. There
may have been some original connexion between the signs \[ \text{niini} \]
and \[ \text{dam} \] which only differ by a single stroke, and they are
both represented by the Latin Dominus and Domina.

422. Alti. \[ \text{alti} \] a Wife. Rendered in Accadian by
\[ \text{dam} \] Dam. Thus the goddess ( . . . . ) is the Alti or wife
of the god ( . . . . ). 2 R 18, 40. The same expression occurs on
other tablets.

Another word for 'wife' is Ashat, see No. 57, of which the
following is a new example.
&c., &c. [This ornament belongs] to Hipa wife of [Sinesses]. 
Sha Hipa ashat-zu sha Sinesses. North British Review, No. 105, 
p. 234 (correcting an error).

423. **Dam.** a Consort: used (like the Latin *conjug*), for 
either husband or wife. It is an Accadian word.

2 R 10, line 2. If a wife to her 
husband [shall say] my husband [thou art not]....

In line 9 these words recur, but with an opposite meaning: 
“if a husband to his wife shall say ‘thou art not my wife’.... 
&c., &c.” In consequence probably of this ambiguity of meaning 
we frequently find after the name of a god, that of the goddess his 
wife thus expressed dam-bi shal ‘his female consort.’

424. **Shal makra.** a Concubine. Means 
literally, ‘an additional or irregular or casual wife.’ The word 
makra is the Heb. מַקְרָה fortuitus: thus, the second month of 
Adar, called Ve-Adar by the Hebrews, was called by the Assyrians 
Arakhu makru ‘the casual month’ See Norris’s Dictionary p. 50.

Oppert’s Khors. Inscr. pl. 12, l. 3. “I destroyed his city. 
I carried off his wife, his sons and daughters, his wealth and 
treasures, his concubines, the regalia of his palace, with the people 
of his land. I left none of them.” Here the word used is 
It occurs also in a curious passage in 
2 R 16, col. ii, 67. “Shal makra sha bil-su imsu-su, ibbati 
khisukhta-su-ma innapiritsi: the concubine whom her lord neg-
lects, will break to pieces her pretty trinkets that she loved.” The 
verb in this sentence is a tense of the Heb. פּוֹל ‘to break.’ 
Ibbati from Heb. פּוֹל pulcher.

425. **Zikriti.** Concubines. (Some-
times written without the ). Often mentioned as captured 
along with the family and treasures of a monarch. Assur. p. 132, 
165, 200, &c.

426. **Marhita.** a Wife. See 2 R 36, lines 44 
and 46, where it is explained by khirta and ashata.
Related to the Arabic Marra or Mara, ʃa a woman or wife. It seems to be a diminutive, like ummanita from umman 'mother.'

427. Khirat. ʃa ʃa a Wife: otherwise ʃa ʃa Khirtu: plur. ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa Khirati. Gula the great goddess, wife (khirat) of the meridian sun (1 Mich. iv. 6). The gods and their great wives, khirati-sun rabati. Botta 153, 12.

ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa Khiraita (wife) was the name of one of the goddesses, who was queen of the city called Susanna, otherwise Sisanna. 2 R 59, 18 and 60, 17: of which name the god Sin ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa forms an integral part.

428. Amilu. ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa or ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa a Man. A very common word on the tablets, but little used in the historical inscriptions, except in the Persian period: gen. Amili ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa Amilu Parsai, a Persian (see No. 103). Plur. Amilut ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa Sha amilut iddinnu, sha tuki ana amilut iddinnu, who men gave, who their fortunes to men gave.

Amilutu is likewise used in the singular, and written ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ex. gr. lú sarru, lú issakku, lú amilutu mala suma nabu whether he be a king, or a priest, or any man however his name is called.

429. Imatti. ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa the Right Hand: put for imanti from ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa 'dexter,' as libitta for libinta.

The god ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa or Im was the Jupiter Tonans of the Latins. We read that the lightnings of Im (ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa rikhisti Im) were held in his right hand (as imatti Im) where the meaning is clearly ascertained by the Accadian version ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa It zida being the Right Hand.

430. Simta. ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa ʃa a Fabric. (Heb. שומ to make, compose or put together).

"O Fire! of every thing which can be named, the fabric thou makest! Of bronze and lead the melter art thou! Of gold and silver the purifier art thou!" The first of these lines stands thus in the original: Nin sha suma nabú simta taskan-ma. Here Nin
must mean 'everything.' It usually means 'nothing' or 'no one.' Similar changes occur in other languages: thus the French aucun originally meant 'some,' but now it has the meaning of 'none.'

431. **Atmu.** Food. 3R 58, No. 5 (sometimes has a final vowel 𒂗𒂗 or ). Atmu kienu as pi nisi ishkan, 'there shall be abundant food in the mouths of men.'—In Oppert's Sargon, folio edition, in the description of a famine: Atmu risiti (the food of the poor) edir-imma (was entirely wanting). This verb is privatus fuit: diminutus fuit: defuit. (Schindler).

The etymology of Atmu is rather doubtful. We may compare the Heb. אכ "to eat."

432. **Takabar.** Copper (Accadian). A very frequent word. Esar. vi, 8, of a new palace: Sikkat kaspa ibbi u takabar namri urattá kireb-sha, 'with plates of pure silver and polished copper I lined its interior.'

433. **Kiebar.** Copper. In 2R 18, 54 the Accadian takabar kim is rendered in Assyrian kimą kiebar. And so it is in other places.

Kiebar seems related to Cuprum: ἄξενος Cyprium: Copper; and even the Accadian Takabar seems referable to the same root.

434. **Pasalli.** Sculptured images of metal. Heb. פסלי sculptura, idolum. 3R 13, 29. Sennacherib placed in his new palace great beams (timmi danni) of cypress, cedar, and other woods which were covered with pasalli (images) and kaspi (silver). Compare Isaiah xxx, 22. פסלי כְּכֶם pasili kaspa, idols of silver.

435. **Padi.** a Sceptre. Nabiu nash padi tsirti tsirti, 'Nebo bearing the sceptre lofty ... lofty' .... (the rest is broken off). The Accadian renders padi by 𒂗𒂗 'sceptre' (see No.141 of the Glossary) and gives a complete sense, viz. Gathula (lifting up) 𒂗𒂗 (the lofty sceptre) sidie (governing) 𒂗𒂗 (mankind).

Similarly, Neriglissar says that Nebo had given him his own sceptre of justice, to rule the people, and govern the land—R 67, 12, and similar mentions of the divine sceptre of Nebo are frequent.
436. Ἀnat. θαλάτης a Goddess. Feminine of θαλάτης Ἰλυ 'a god' (No. 1 of this Glossary). Occurs rarely. Prayer of Assurbanipal to Ishtar of Arbola [Assur. p. 121] Umma atti bilat biliti, O thou queen of queens; ilat kabli, goddess of war; bilat takhasi, lady of battles; malikat ili, queen of the gods!—In page 277 we have another example.—Beltis the great goddess, kadirti ilati, written θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή.

437. Shadu. θαλάτης (or θαλάτης Ἰλυ), (often merely θαλάτης) A Lord. Heb. θαλάτης dominus, θαλάτης domina. Ex. from a tablet θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή θαλάτης Ἰλυ Shadu rubu, the great lord, Ἀνατολή ab'i father [of the god . . . .]. On an old transcript which I have of K 33 I find a singular passage θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή θαλάτης Ἰλυ Shadu linir kunusi, "May the Lord enlighten you!" (θαλάτης to enlighten, teach, instruct). This is repeated no less than nine times, but the verb, in the optative mood, is varied each time. The nine optatives are as follows: I am at present unable to explain them.

θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή linir. θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή linikh.
θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή likattin. θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή likhitis. θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή libuhi.
θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή likla. θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή liktum. θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή libnuka.

By the phrase 'may the Lord protect you!' is meant the Chief of the gods, Assur at Nineveh, probably Marduk at Babylon. Compare R 37, 10 θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή θαλάτης Ἰλυ Ἀνατολή Ashur shadu rubu.

438. θαλάτης a King. The pronunciation is unknown. Mr. G. Smith, No. 330, renders it Sar, but this is only the meaning, not the sound.

This is a very interesting word, being evidently identical with the Scytho-Median θαλάτης 'a King,' which Norris in p. 18 of his memoir on the Scythic language (Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society, vol. xv.) renders (provisionally only) as Ko, and of which the true phonetic value has never been discovered.
It occurs frequently on the astrological tablets, for instance \(3R60, 96\) \(\text{Sar kussati ilabbar}\) the king of the nation shall grow old upon his throne. In l. 102 also \(\text{gu'a 'the throne.'}\)

439. **Irsu.** \(\text{a King. In B.M. 38, 2 and R 43, 2 Sennacherib is called Lulimu irsu 'the noble king.' In 3R 12, 1 the phrase is Irsu itpisu, for which Taylor has Rihu itpisu, while Oppert (folio p. 15, 34) has Sarru itpisu.}\)

440. **Ukku.** \(\text{a King. (meant 'great man:' identical with the Medo-Scythic ukku 'great,' see Norris's Scythic vocabulary p. 181). Several examples of this word occur in 2R 47, which are all rendered by the Assyrian Sar. The phrase Sar ana Sar, king to king (sends greeting) is rendered Uk ku Uk; the syntax of which is, Uk ku (unto a king) Uk (another king) sends greeting. This phrase Sar ana Sar is common on the Omen tablets.}\)

441. **Lila,** the Night. More examples of this important word are desirable (see some in No. 25). I find the following on a tablet: *Lila ana mazarti tushasib, usib:* 'at night thou didst set me to watch; and I sat (watching).' Here *lila* is written \(\text{innun-ku.}\)

The Accadian version of *ana mazarti* is *innun-ku.*

442. **Lilita.** \(\text{a Goblin of the Night. This is a very interesting word, because it is exactly the Hebrew Spectrum Nocturnum. In a numerous list of sprites and demons the following occurs Lú lilú, lú lilita "whether it be a male or female goblin of the night."}\)

443. **Gallil.** \(\text{verb, to be wicked. (Amilut) lú ugalil, lú udammik, nin val idi: 'no one knows (of a man) whether he be wicked, or whether he be righteous.' The meaning of the two verbs is fixed by the Accadian translation (wicked) and (righteous). [The second verb dammik is very common and its meaning well known.]}\)

444. **Gallú.** \(\text{an Evil Spirit, sometimes written In Accadian. Apparently derived from the verb gallil 'to be wicked,' see last article. These}\)
spirits are frequently mentioned, and the epithet 'wicked' is given to them. They had sometimes the form of bulls, and were very injurious to men. The Accad version is 'like an evil spirit.' The Accad version is

445. Nara, (verb) to Help or Succour. I have only found this verb, which is the root of the common word Nirarut 'assistance,' in the following passage 3 R 15,9. A battle was impending during a hazardous expedition to recover his father's throne. Esarhaddon had prayed to the gods. The divine response was: Alik! la katta! idu-ka nittallak, ninara girri-ka: "go! fear not! we march by thy side, we assist thy expedition!" The verbs are written nittallak, and ninara.

Katta is a doubtful word, but may be the Heb. 'timor.'

Perhaps the phrase Shadu linir kunusi! in No. 437 should be rendered "May the Lord help you!" from the verb nara of this article.

446. Ida, to Help. In Assur. p. 68, the king of Lydia submits to Assurbanipal saying "the King whom God assists, art Thou!" Sar sha Il idu su, atta! Ida comes from Id 'the side' Heb. To help a person, to take his side. Hence the further use of the Heb. in the sense of auxilium.

Perhaps idu in the above sentence is a substantive. We might translate "the King who God is (by) his side, art Thou!"

447. Khisa, to make haste, Heb. festinavit. In R 41,16 it is related that Suzub the Chaldean returned in great haste from the land of Elam, and seized the crown of Babylon: ultu Nura-ki ikhis-amma. He then stripped off the gold from the temples of Bel and Zirpanita, and sent it to Umman-Minan king of Elam, as a bribe, with this urgent appeal for help:

Bukkhir umman-ko, collect thy army!
Diká karasi-ka, strike thy camp!

ana Babel khis-amma, make haste to Babylon!

idá-ni ziz, stand by our side!

In my version of bukkhir and dika I follow Norris Dict. 474.

The use of בְּרֵעַ in Hebrew is quite similar. Ps. xxii, 19. haste thee (to help me!). Furst says: "to haste to, with לְ of the person"—which would be ana in Assyrian. Thus: Khisa ana Babel, 'haste to Babylon,' would be in Hebrew בְּרֵעַ לְבָבֶל.

Ziz frequently means 'to stand.' Thus in Assur. p. 124 makhar-sha taxiz thou didst stand before her.

448. Etik, to change; forsake; remove from. Heb. יִתְבוֹא dimovit, transtulit. In Assur. p. 41, we read that Necho and the other kings of Egypt adie Assur etiku 'forsook the faith of Assur.' Hence I see that the passage quoted in No. 324 ought to have been translated "the queen of the Arabians," sha mamit Shamas titiku "who has now forsaken the worship of the Sun."

449. Zahin, to Adorn. Assur. p. 156. Ikbud limut, he devised evil, ana ekim makhazi, to capture the holy cities, subat Ili, the dwellings of the gods, sha isriti-sun uddisu, whose temples I had restored, uzahinu khuraza ukaspa, and had adorned them with gold and silver, kireb-sun astakkanu simati, and had placed treasures within them. (See also No. 224.)

450. Naplits, to Bless, to regard with favour. Bit-ka naplits! alu-ka naplits! bless thy temple, bless thy city! Babilu u bit Sagagathu naplits! bless Babylon and the temple of Sagagathu!

Ana bit Tara khadish naplits! bless joyfully the temple of Tara! Senk. ii, 17. The verb is written
in this passage, and also in Birs. N. ii, 18 and R 52, 25 without variation of spelling. In Oppert's "Inscription of Khorsabad," l. 12, Ili rabi (the great gods) \( \text{Ili rabi} \) ispaluni (blessed me). In same, l. 188, Hekali satina Assur abu ili in nummur bun-su illiti kinish lippalis! \( \text{Hekali satina Assur abu ili in nummur bun-su illiti kinish lippalis!} \) lippalis, may he bless (those palaces!) On a tablet concerning a man afflicted with an evil spirit “Marduk ippalitzu, Marduk will look on him with pity”: written \( \text{Marduk ippalitzu} \). Again, in Assur. p. 290 Anaku khalish appalis-su, ‘I inclined myself to him with favour’—written \( \text{Anaku khalish appalis-su} \). The change of \( \text{E} \) for \( \text{E} \) (see last example) is rather capricious.

This verb naplits is a quadriliteral, unless we suppose it a niphal form from palis.

451. \( \text{Arar} \), to Curse. Agrees exactly with the Hebrew אָרַר maledixit: execratus est.

\( \text{Liruru} \), may they curse! Michaux stone col. iv, 24 “May the gods whose names are written on this stone, curse him with a curse which cannot be removed! arrat la napsuri liruru-su!” And so in Tiglath Pileser’s inscription Arrati marusta liruru-su!’ may they curse him with perilous curses! R. 16, 76.

452. \( \text{Gur} \), \( \text{Gur} \) to Scold, or Reprehend. Exactly the Heb. יָכִין increpitum, objurgavit aliquem, ut pater filium, יָכִין et increpitum eum pater ejus’ Gen. xxxvii, 10 (Gesenius).

In 2 R 10, 15 is one of the old laws of Assyria.

Apilu (if a master) arda igur-ma (shall scold his servant, and); imtut ikhtalik (shall threaten him with death)........ &c. &c. [he shall pay a heavy fine.]

453. \( \text{Kubie} \), \( \text{Kubie} \) Curses. \( \text{I:zarrakh-su} \) (he will be enraged with him) \( \text{kubie igabnu-su} \) (and will speak curses unto him). This is the Hebrew כְּבֵי. Gesenius says: כְּבֵי maledixit: execratus est (Numbers xxiii, 13) כְּבֵי “Curse me them from thence!” (story of Balakam).

Another example: \( \text{Kubie agabbi} \) (I spoke curses, or sharp words) manman val isiman-anni (but no one heard). In these two
examples kubie is used in conjunction with the verb gabba ‘to speak,’ and seems derived from it. I believe that kubie meant originally ‘words.’ Gesenius states, what is very important, that the verb כְּבִי is the same as כְּבִי which sometimes means ‘to curse,’ but sometimes simply ‘to speak or name.’ Hence we perceive the true connexion of the Assyrian verb gabba ‘to speak’ so constantly used, with the Hebrew, namely that it is the verb כְּבִי reduced to כְּבִי by the rejection of the initial N.

454. Guk. or the monogram to Swell: perhaps to Burst. This seems to be the Heb. or erupit: prorupit: effusus est.

Tarku king of Ethiopia had captured Memphis which belonged to Assurbanipal. Allaku khanthu (a rapid messenger) as kireb Ninua illik-amma (came to Nineveh) usanni yaati (and told me the news). Eli ipsiti unnati (on account of these doings) libbi igug (my heart swelled) izzarukh kabatti (and my liver was enraged). Assur. p. 17.

455. Zarikh, to be enraged—to burst with rage. Heb. supercrevit (to swell greatly): effusus est (to burst).

izzarrakh, he will be enraged (phrase on a tablet). izzarukh kabatti, my liver swelled with rage. Assur. p. 17, but in this passage Oppert (Egyptian Campaigns p. 64) reads izzarikh. Compare also the phrase tsirikha igabbi ‘he will speak angry words;’ and that in Assur. p. 212 Suparamati annati as tsirikhti libbi-ya, “concerning these matters in the indignation of my heart [I took up arms, &c.]” written tsirikhti.

456. Kallam, to Speak. A purely Arabic word, used of divine speech, ex. gr. kalam Allah, ‘the word of God,’ which came to Jonah. (Jonah i, 1, Wright’s edition).

Ukallimu ‘they spoke’ Tukallima ‘thou spakest.’ In Assur. p. 235 the gods, who had uttered a prophecy in ancient times,
"now spoke it again to later people" eninna ukallima nisi arkati. And in Assur. p. 250 a passage perfectly similar, except that it is in the second person, tukallima "thou spakest it again to later people."

457. Anakhut. an Injury. Chald. afflictus est. In 3 R plate 4 No. 4 Suzub king of Babylon irsa anakhat, sustained an injury [by falling from his horse]. In Assur. p. 239, a grandson of Marduk-Baladan heard very bad news, and tktum libba-su (his heart was smitten) irsa anakuttu (he sustained great affliction): napista-su panús-su val igir (his life had no value in his sight): ikhounka mitutu (he wished for death). He said to his swordbearer, 'slay me with the sword!' Then he and his swordbearer slew each other.

The two spellings of anakhat differ, but the verb irsa being the same identifies the word.

Besides this use of the word anakhat, it occurs continually in the following phrase, "In future times, when these buildings shall grow old and decay, blessed be the king my successor who shall repair their injuries!" (ankhut-zun luttish). Or, when only one palace is spoken of, ankhut-sa luttish.

458. Enakh, (verb) to be Injured: to Decay (Chald. This and the last No. apparently belong to the same root: they generally occur together.

Enuma sigurratu shatina usalbaru enakhu, when these towers shall grow old and decay.—Tig. viii, 52. Enuma hekal satu ilabbiru inakhu, Esar. vi, 61 written The same phrase in Bellino 63, but written innakhu.

459. Arba. to Catch in a Snare. Heb. insidiatus est. In 3 R 4 No. 4, Sennacherib goes in chase of four large eagles, among the mountains. He says: "Two of them maskanati arba I caught with (nets?).

460. Belbel, to Melt Heb. fudit. Sha eriu anaki mubullil-sun atta, Thou, O Fire, art the melter of brass and lead. (tablet).
461. **Shallal.** to Spoil: *subst.* Spoil. Agrees exactly with the Heb. spoliavit.

\[ \text{Asallal (I will carry off) the people of Shushan, &c.} \]

Assur. 179. *Isallal* occurs 3 R 56, 17 *mat isallal*, he will plunder the land. *Salal*, the spoil, or carrying off, of his god Masdia. Opp. Khors. ix, 3. These forms are comparatively rare: but *ashlula* 'I spoiled' occurs very frequently.—*Sha sarri Elam makhruti istulu*, [all the valuables] "which the former kings of Elam had carried off." Written *istulu*. Assur. p. 226.

462. **Makhar**, to Pray. *Amkhur* or *Amkhar* 'I prayed'—ex. gr. *Assur u Ishtar amkhur* I prayed to Assur and Ishtar. (Assur. p. 191). *Amkhar sakuti Ishtar*, I prayed to the lofty Ishtar (Assur. 120). *As sat musi suatu sha amkhuru-si* in the nighttime of that night in which I had prayed to her (Assur. p. 123)—*Ki sha ana Assur amkhuru*, as I had prayed to Assur [so it fell out]. Assur. p. 67.

*T* conjugation *Imdakharunima* they besought me. Assur. p. 81.

463. **Labat**, to Overthrow. Agrees with the Heb. praeceps ruinit: praecipitavit: praeceps ruinit.

*S* conjugation *Sulbit*, ex. gr. *Isriti Elam adi la basi usalbit*, I overthrew the temples of Elam until none were left.

464. **Lebesh**, to Clothe. The same in Hebrew, vestivit.

Assur. p. 27. *Lubultu birmi ulabbis-su*, 'I clothed him with scarlet raiment.' Written *Sallbis*. Phill. i, 37. *Papakha Nabiu sha kireb bit-saggathu, sibbu-su, sigaru-su, u babnaku-su khurassi usalbis*. "The chapel of Nebo which is within the temple of Saggathu, its gates, its doors and its . . . . with gold I covered." Written *usalbis*. This verb is a common one.

465. **Kala**, to Speak, a rather doubtful word, suggested by the two following examples, and the analogy of the Hebrew *Vox*
A GLOSSARY OF THE

\[\text{he did not utter prayers.} \quad \text{Liki unnini-ya. Simi kala-ya. "Receive my prayers! Hear my voice!" This latter example I have considered in No. 379. The occurrence of unnini in each suggests that Kala (voice) and ika (he spoke), have a common origin.}\]

466. Sunukh, to Repeat. Heb. \[\text{iteravit. Ikribi-ya sunukhuti, "my repeated prayers." Written }\]

467. Zibu. \[\text{a kind of Antelope. Heb. Dorcas. A tablet mentions Zibu surrukhu 'swift antelopes.' The word stands between ga makhe 'fine oxen' and tsieni (…) sheep. The epithet given to the sheep I do not know. Offerings to the gods are here spoken of. Similar offerings are mentioned in Opp. Khors. l. 172, where the epithet surrukhi is given to another animal (called ) and the Zibi or antelopes ( ) have the epithet illuti 'excellent,' while another animal has the epithet ibbuti 'pretty.' In both these texts, it will be observed, occurs, I must leave it doubtful whether it is an animal or the epithet of one.}\]

Mr. Norris's translation of Opp. Khors. l. 172, will be found in his dictionary p. 308. He thinks the Zibi were birds, because a bird of that name is mentioned in 2 R 37, 4.

The Syriac form of \[\text{is tabia . The Assyrian inscriptions very seldom name any females. One exception is the princess Tabna whom Esarhaddon (iii, 13) appointed to be queen over a Syrian or Arabian nation. I think her name meant Dorcas, as that was a favourite female name. 468. Nimru, a Leopard. Heb. \[\text{Pardus. Nimri, leopards, together with many other wild animals, in my Calah I collected.—B.M. 44, 19.}\]
The spots on this animal may be compared to Eyes. This affords a very simple etym of the Hebrew יָעֵץ, viz. from the Assyrian Namri in the sense of Eyes or Vision.

469. Urbarra. אַרְבָּא אֲרִי a Tiger (?). It is frequently said in the omen tablets, "If the weather and seasons are so-and-so, nanthur Urmakh Urbarra, Lions and Tigers (?) will be seen. 3 R 61, col. ii, 10. The translation is conjectural.

470. Mu. מְוִי Water. Chald. מְוִי which singular is not found in Hebrew, but only the plural מְוִי or מְוִי. Josephus gives Mω, from which he derives the name of Moses. The plural Mie 'waters' is very common in Assyrian, but the singular is comparatively rare, and therefore I will give an example or two of it. Speaking of the Euphrates: "Mu-sha as abzie kinish kunnū its water . . . . in the Ocean." Sometimes it is written simply מְוִי ex. gr. elish isaggu mu, from above they drank water (Ch. אֶלְיָהּ bibit). Here the Accadian translation of מְוִי by מְוִי 'water' identifies its meaning.

471. Aminna. אָמִינה (Accad.) a kind of Crown. Evidently derived from Amia 'a crown' (see No. 404). In 2 R 30, 19 Aminna is explained by Agú elú 'lofty crown.'

472. Izkati. אִזְקָטִי Fetters. Exactly the Hebrew אִזְקָטִי catena, vincula, Jerem. xl, 1. As biriti anbar, izkati anbar, utammikhu kati u shapie, with bonds of iron and fetters of iron they held their hands and feet. Assur. p. 26 (same words in p. 44). As zizzi izkati anbar, biriti anbar utammikh, [two chiefs] in strong fetters of iron and bonds of iron he bound. Assur. p. 66; and same words in Assur. p. 113.

473. Sigaru. סִגָּר Chains. Probably from the Hebrew root סִגָּר to lock or close (Levit. xiii, 4, to imprison a person).

In Assur. p. 261, Sigaru askun-su, 'I placed chains on him' [and threw him into the great central prison of Nineveh.]

474. Zulul. צָלוּל Shade. Heb. צָלוּל obumbrate. Ikhtallubu kishti sha zulul-sin rapsu, they passed through forests
whose shade was vast. Assur. p. 267. Norris p. 348, gives the form Zalul. In that passage I think it means the shade of an umbrella of state.

Zalul is very frequently used for 'the roof of a building,' which shades it. E.I.H. ix. 8. "Tall Cedars, the growth of lofty mountains, I laid for its roof, ana zululi-sha usatriz." Written Zululi. And in E.I.H. col. iii. in the account of the splendours of the chapel of Nebo, Zululu occurs several times. Ex.gr. "The Cedar roof of the Kua (shrine or oracle) I covered with shining silver, usalbis kaspi namri. Another roof I covered with gold and precious stones," &c. &c.

475. Zubati. Victims. Heb. Zubah hostia: victima. I find the following passage in an address to the deity, asking for pardon of sins, and varying the phrase in different ways. Killati-ya mahadati kima zubati sukhat! "Slay my many sins, as if they were victims!" This prayer realizes to us one of the primitive ideas and objects of sacrifice. In slaying the victim (the Sin-Offering) the sin was also slain or destroyed. So in Leviticus, chap. 1, when any man of the children of Israel brought a sheep gont or bullock to the door of the tabernacle, he first put his hand upon its head, to transfer his own guilt upon the victim, and after that it was sacrificed.

I must remark that sukhat was a verb proper to sacrifices, the Hebrew mactavit pecudem; ex.gr. Levit. i, 5, 'and he shall kill the bullock.'

The Accadian translation of kima zubati is ku kim. Hence the name of a victim in Accadian was Ku. And the term for 'a sacrificing priest' was Bil Ku 'master of sacrifice,' see Assur. 184 and again p. 186 with prefixed, denoting 'an office.'

476. Zibi. Vultures. In Assur. p. 166 some criminals are put to death, and the king says: "I gave their flesh to be eaten by dogs, wolves(? vulture-birds (zibi-khu): eagle-birds (it-khu, the birds of heaven and the fishes of the deep. In 2 R 37, 4 in a long list of birds, we find the Zibu
explained Kharrukhai, which in Mr. Norris's opinion (Dictionary, p. 308) means 'bird of the desert.' I suppose from Heb. חָרְבוֹן, Arab. حَرْبُون (Sch. p. 653) related to חָרְבוֹן, חָרְבוֹן, חָרְבוֹן, &c., implying desolation from extreme dryness—burnt-up land. This etym seems not improbable.

477. Zibi. GIFTS.

Natan zibi, a giving of gifts i.e. liberality. In Tig. vii, 52 and the Annals i, 25 the King is praised for his pious care of the temples: Ipšit kati-su u natan-zibi-su ili rabi itibu (or iramu) 'the works of his hands and his great generosity pleased the gods.'

Zibi may come from a verb ziba 'to give,' which I find in 2 R 13, 37 Siparta-su (his money) la shakilta (not weighed, i.e. without stint) sha ana sibruti izilu (which he had given for . . . .). And I think it occurs also in the name of the temple of Ziba-tila (giver of life) an epithet of the goddess Gula at Babylon.

478. Zariri. GOLD (?).

This appears to be the Persian Zar 'gold,' a word which may have become known to the Assyrians in very ancient times. In Botta pl. 18 quater; pl. 152; and elsewhere it is said: "I offered to the gods katri of pure gold and bright silver, katri zariri russi, kasbu ibbi." Now, russi is the standing epithet of 'gold,' insomuch that the Accadian is rendered in Assyrian khuraza russá (see No. 400). Hence I think that the substantive joined to it in the preceding passage of Botta probably means 'gold.' In the other texts in which zariri occurs the meaning of 'gold' suits very well. E.I.H. iii, 10 (quoted by Norris p. 382) "I adorned the shrine of Marduk with zariri and abni (with gold and precious stones)." Also, Assur. p. 227 "I captured fine chariots of various descriptions sha akhitzu-sin zariri zakhalú, whose exterior was gilt and adorned with figures." Compare E.I.H. ix, 12 "doors, &c., ikhitz kaspa khurassu, whose exterior was silver and gold." Heb. חָרְבוֹן 'exterior.'

It appears to me, that in Elam the Persian words Zar 'gold' and Sim 'silver' were current, but that they were usually employed with the Persian case-ending ra (making Zar-ra and Sim-ra). For, when Assurbanipal took Susa, the capital of Elam,
(Assur. p. 226) he carried off all the 'pure gold' zarirú russú, and 'bright silver' ismarú ibblú, of the Elamite kings. Here ismarú (or simarú) is written 〈〈〈 Ἐ Ἐ Ἐ〉〉〈.

If this is correct, a further consequence is, that Zar and Sim are very ancient Persian words.

479. Ismarú. 〈〈〈 Ἐ Ἐ Ἐ〉〉〈 Silver. See preceding article for one example. Another is found in E.I.H. iii, 56 in the account of the very splendid decorations of the chapel of Nebo. Not only were the cedar roofs plated with silver, but the very approaches were equally splendid. Tallakti papakha (the path to the chapel) u malaku bit (and the way to the temple) aguri ismarí 〈〈〈 Ἐ Ἐ Ἐ〉〉〈 "with slabs of silver" 〈〈〈 Ἐ Ἐ Ἐ〉〉〈 gubú "were paved." 〈〈〈 Ἐ Ἐ Ἐ〉〉〈 reads 'aguri,' the i being borrowed from the next word (in quick pronunciation). Agurri are slabs or flat plates of any kind, ex.gr. of alabaster—agurri zamat illiti. E.I.H. col. iii.

The last two words of the above translation "were paved" require a particular examination. In the East India House slab lithographed in the British Museum series plate 54 they stand thus (line 57) 〈〈〈 Ἐ Ἐ Ἐ〉〉〈 gubú. But here Porter's transcript, which is of equal authority with the India House slab, differs from it very notably, reading 〈〈〈 Ἐ Ἐ Ἐ〉〉〈 Agurri ismarí gubuthu. This verb gubuthu I propose to render "they were paved." Indeed, I think that we have here the Hebrew word Gabbatha 'a pavement,' which is found in the New Testament (John xix, 13) "He sat down in a place that is called the Pavement, (λιθοστρωτον) but in the Hebrew Gabbatha." This is the more interesting since Hebrew and Syriac scholars seem unable to confirm by other examples this interpretation of gabbatha. But here we have it, if I am not mistaken, preserved in the Assyrian language.

480. Busha. 〈〈〈 Ἐ Ἐ Ἐ〉〉〈 Treasures. R 63, 20, of a Palace. "Former kings busha-sun in kirbi unakkimu, stored up their treasures within it." A very common word.

481. Garsu. 〈〈〈 Ἐ Ἐ Ἐ〉〉〈 Wealth. Treasure. Opp. Khors. 10, l. 87
[I carried off his gold and silver] *garsu hekali-su sha niba la isú*, 'the treasures of his palace which had no number' [were innumerable]. This word is very common. It may be the Persian *Gaza*, Ch. and Syr. *Ganza*.

482. **Risiti.**  the First, or Best. From *Ris* or *Rish* 'the first.' Heb. 

Bellino l. 20 and Sen. B.l. 9 (see 3 R 12) "I sacrificed one bull, ten sheep, ten Kuruni (some horned animal(?), probably deer): twenty (animals) kalima risiti-su "the best of every kind." I think these twenty comprise the preceding ten sheep and ten deer, and it is merely added that they were victims of especial beauty. *Kalima* 'of every kind' is a very common word.

483. **Khallul.**  to Clothe.

*Zabi sunuti sha naru suatu ikhrú*, "those soldiers who had dug that canal" [with yellow cloth and scarlet dresses] *ukhallul sunuti* "I clothed them." Written Bavian 33. In R 19, 93 the king executes a Rebel Chief. *Akutz tzu-su* (or *masak-su*), *Dur sha ali Ninua ukhallul*. "I flayed off his skin, and with it clothed the wall of the palace of Nineveh." This is repeated two or three times in the same page, with some variations. Dr. Hincks first explained the meaning. In this second example *ukhallul* is written exactly as in the Bavian inscription.

"The Cedar roof of the chapel of Nebo with gold I covered," *ukhallilu* Porter's transcript of E.I.H. iii, 45. The India House slab has *usalbush* "I clothed," the S conjugation of *לָבשׁ* 'to clothe.'

484. **Zalukh,** to Pour. Chald. *fluxit*; whence *Imbres*.

In Opp. Khors. l. 131 the king destroys the enemy: *Azlish unakkis* "I cut them off like azli;" *imat múti azlukha*, "and I poured upon them the storm of death." Written azlukha. Sargon l. 29 is very similar. *Gimir bakhulati-sun azlish udabikhu* "all their people he slaughtered like azli;" *as mati nakhiri izlubku imat múti* "and upon the hostile lands he poured a storm of death." Here Oppert reads *naplish* instead of *azlish*, and the correction *as mati* is due to him. *Izlukhu* is written .
The meaning is fixed by the somewhat similar passage of Nerigl. i, 27 quoted by Norris, p. 482, which substitutes for izlukhu the verb izannu 'they pour down' which almost always denotes Rain and Storms.

485. Dabakh, to Slaughter. Chald. ἀποκτόνει, but in Hebrew ἀποκτόνησαν 'mactavit peculem.'

udabikhu 'he slaughtered;' see the preceding article. The letter is omitted in some copies.

486. Shur, to set Free, to Liberate. Chald. ἀπολύω solvit (ex. gr. de vinculis. Ges.). Dan. iii, 25 "Lo! I see four men loose" (soluti). In R 39, 7. Sittuti-sun (the rest of them) who had committed no crime, usshur-sun akbi (I commanded them to be set at liberty). Written usshur. This seems to be a Hiphil form of the verb.

487. Tillukh. ἐπιμελέωμαι to Meditate. Schindler's Lexicon gives us the verb ἐπιμελέωμαι meaning in Chald. and Syr. 'to doubt' and in Arabic 'to think' or 'meditate.'

Old proverb: As tami ussus, as musi tillukh; "Work by day: think by night." Schindler's example of ἐπιμελέωμαι "meditatus sum nocte" is very apposite. Psalm 77. The word ussus is doubtful; the Accadian renders it by the verb gu (reduplicated). But in another passage ussa is rendered or by the verb du 'to go' (reduplicated). 'Activity' seems to be meant.

488. Naziq, to Hurt or Injure. Chald. ἀποκτόνει (Aphel in Ezra inaziq) Lusit, nocuit, damno affecit, (Schindler). Asakku sha mat inazzakhu (or inaziqu) "Demons who hurt mankind." For which reason the later Chaldeans called them Maziqi (or Hurters) see Schindler p. 1101. Maziq. Daemon nocens hominibus: and more about them in Buxtorf p. 1325.

Mat, sometimes Matu is very often used for people—men—mankind, &c. It is rendered in Accadian by , sometimes by .

Other examples:
Libba-su nazkhu 'his heart is hurt.' In 2 R 38, 34 the king gives to the gods a great number of precious stones. He names nine or ten kinds, and then says: u abni il, sha mu-su nazqu, written This, I think, may mean "and other stones whose names are injured"—viz., in the record which the scribe was copying. I prefer this to the translation given in No. 60.

The Accadian has Ziga "to hurt."

489. Asakku. a Daemon or Goblin. Probably from nazik 'to hurt,' because they harmed men (see last article). They were called in Accadian Itpa.

490. Udukku. or sometimes merely an Evil Spirit: in Accadian The old Babylonians were firm believers in demoniacal possession, and practised exorcism or the casting out of unclean spirits. A tablet published some years ago by the British Museum (2 R 18) has not yet attracted the attention it deserves. It says, of a sick man, "May the goddess . . . . wife of the god . . . . pani-su ana ashri shanuma likun, turn his face in another direction, udukku sinu litzi-ma, as akhati lizbat, that the evil spirit may come out of him, and be thrust aside: sidi tuki, lamassi tuki, as zumri-su lu-kayan, that good spirits and good powers may dwell in his body. 2 R 18, 41. Written lu-kayan.

491. Kimi. some small animals good for food.

It is said of certain malignant daemons, that they devour men as if they were Kimi. Matu kima kimi igammu. The verb is the Chald. gama 'to swallow' Matu is rendered in Accadian by ; kima kimi by ku kim; and igamma by written twice, with added. This probably means 'eating,' being composed of placed within the sign Ka, or mouth.

But what are Kimi? I find them in a list (apparently) of small birds in 2 R 5, 38 with the Accadian version Kuda
which is probably a mere variant of 𒅠šušan ša hu. I think therefore
that we may translate—these heroes men as if they were sparrows.”

492. Im. 𒈗𒅷  a Storm. Botta 44 𒉐𒂈šušan ša hu. 𒅠šušan ša 𒌋𒂆 𒔄
𒆨𒈗, 𒍒, 𒍧 𒏎 𒉕 𒂋组委会 (sašušan ša umbingiakku-su),
like a wild wind I swept over it’ viz. the land of Babylonia. And,
on a tablet ᅩ𒃹 ša ᅩ𒃹 ša hu bari kiškuš-su maranta ral idi,
which like a great tempest, no one knows its course.

493. Imat. 𒉕𒉑  or 𒉕𒈗  𒉕𒉑 a Storm. Appears to be
the same as the preceding, grammatically written.

Among the figures set up to guard Nebiglissar’s palace were eight
šušan ša hu kiškuš-su šušan nišam imat muti, eight beasts
of bronze very fierce looking, which upon criminals and enemies
poured down a storm of death. Nimig. i. 27. See two other
examples of the word ᅩ𒃹 in the article Zalukh ‘to pour,’ No. 484.

494. Nubattu. ᅩ𒂁 𒈩  𒈩 a Festival. 2 R 32, 13.

And Morris p. 371 quotes from Assur Nubattu ša sar ili
Marduk, “the festival of the king of the gods Marduk.” The
word occurs thrice in Mr. Smith’s calendar p. 326-327.

495. Alu. ᅩ𒂀 𒇤  𒇤 a City. ᅩ𒂀 ᅩ𒇤 𒇤 Ali ‘of a city.’
�şim ᅩ𒇤 Ali ‘my city.’ Alusu ‘his city.’

Ninib makin timini alu-su, ana šušan timini rukuti salhú-su!
May Ninib, who laid the foundation of his City, preserve it also
into far distant times!’ Botta 23, 16. Norris p. 31. For Alusi
.enums 𒉏 𒌿 𒉕, other texts read 𒉏 𒍻 𒉕, and Syll. 393 has
𒉏 𒍦 𒉕. Aluisu utzi, he fled from his city
irim 𒉏 𒍾 𒉕, kḫrš fūki. Opp. Khors. l. 41, and l. 114.

496. Ziggurrat. ᅩ𒂁 𒈩  ᅩ𒊯 a Tower.

Assur. 227, Ziggurrat Susem ša āšušan irukti zamatu subulaš,
Likaya, the tower of Shushan which was built of slabs of zamatu
stone I destroyed. And in Tig. viii, 53 enuma sigurratu šatira
usašbaru, ‘when these towers shall grow old.’ Written
𒉏 𒍾 𒉕 𒍪 𒉕 𒍩 𒍾 𒉕. The spelling 𒉏 𒍾 𒉕 𒍪 𒉕 𒍩 𒍾 𒉕 Zikurat also occurs, but only in the inscriptions of Nebuchadnezzar,
see Norris p. 343. In 2 R 50 lines 1—23 is a long list of the principal Ziggurratu of Babylonia, commencing with those of Suanna (a name of Babylon) and Borsippa.

497. Shalkhú. 𒂗𒂗𒂗𒂗 a Fortress. Perhaps from the verb shalkhu to preserve; keep safe; in the same way as the chief tower of a Norman castle was called the Keep. This word occurs frequently. In 2 R 50, 25 we read that Imgur Bel was the Dur of Suanna-ki (Babylon); and Nibit-Bel was its Shalkhú. The exact distinction between the two has not been ascertained: both were fortresses.

498. Rish. 𒂗𒂗𒂗 the Head. gen. 𒂗𒂗𒂗 Risi. (Of a sick man) Musi u urra as risi-su lu-kayan, ‘day and night may it stand at his head!’ (some charm). Written 𒂗𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗. This is varied in 2 R 18, 49 to as risi-su lizbat. Elsewhere to the same effect, as rish amilu ‘at the man’s head’ 𒂗𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗. The symbol 𒂗𒂗𒂗 is written for Rish, and the Accadian often has 𒂗𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 ‘for the head’ ex gr. 2 R 18, 49. But the most usual form is 𒂗𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗.

499. Tsir. 𒂗𒂗𒂗 the Back. plur. 𒂗𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 Tsiri. Obelisk, 1st Epigraph, 𒂗𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 𒂗𒂗 Aabba sha sunai tsiri-sin, Camels with two backs, i.e. two humps on the back. 3 R 4, 49 Irsa anakhat, he met with an accident: valtu tsir kurri kakkarish imkut, from his horse’s back he fell to the earth.

500. Kabat. The Liver (hence metaphorically Anger, Indignation). Also frequently the Heart.

Both the heart and the liver were supposed by the ancients to be the seat of the wrathful passions. Fervens difficili bile tumet jecur. (Hor.) quantà jecur ardeat irà. (Juv.) rabie jecur incendente feruntur (Juv.).

Heb. כבד kabad jecur (same in Arabic). כבד also means ‘animus’ Thren. ii. 11. Ad terram effusum est jecur meum (כבד). Hyperbolice dictum de gravissimo vulnere jecoris, i.e. animi. Gesen.—Figuratively for ‘my heart is wounded.’ Furst.
This word occurs very frequently in the Assyrian writings, but strange to say, it has been overlooked by all, except Oppert (Egyptian Campaigns p. 64). Kabatti (my heart—my liver—my indignation) has, wherever it occurs, been mistaken for Kabitti (great or numerous), of course to the great injury of the sense, which can be cleared up materially in perhaps fifty instances by restoring the true translation.

Yet the Assyrians have been very careful to distinguish the two words, for they always write \(\text{Kabatti}\) (the heart) with the sign \(\text{bat}\), but \(\text{Kabitti}\) (numerous) with the sign \(\text{bit}\).

I will give a good many examples of the word, in order to justify the foregoing remarks.

I. \(\text{Kabatti}\) is the Heart or Liver, i.e. wrath: indignation. Assur. p. 17. Eli ipsiti annati libbi igug-ma, izzarukk kabatti, ‘about these doings my heart swelled, my liver was enraged.’ This is a favorite phrase in the Assyrian writings, recurring in Assur. pages 30 and 38; and twice in the broken cylinder of Esarhaddon (3 R 15 col. i, 2 and col. ii, 13).

II. Nukh kabatti is a frequent phrase. Placere cordi alicujus. Placare iram alicujus. Heb. quiescere, to be calm, also quiescere fecit, tranquillavit (Gesen.) to calm the feelings of another. answers both to placare and placere. Examples. In Assur. 121 the king prays to Ishtar: “O goddess who in the presence of thy father always speakest good of me, so as to gladden the mind of Assur, and please the heart of Marduk” . . . . . . . Here observe the parallelism

\[
\begin{align*}
\text{Suthup libbi Assur} \\
\text{Nukkhi kabatti Marduk}
\end{align*}
\]

The original text is \(\text{Suthup libbi Assur}\)

In Assur. 223 the king ravages the land of Elam. “I destroyed their cities: I made an end of the people who dwelt in them: I broke their gods to pieces (\text{usabbir ili-sun}) and by so doing I calmed the anger of the Lord of Lords (Assur). Written
The two next examples should be compared together, because they illustrate one another. In Assur. 105 Urtaki king of Elam and his chief counsellor come to an evil end. "Libbi Assur aggu (the heart of Assur vengeful) val inukh sunuti (did not let them rest) val ipsukh sunuti (gave them no repose). Kabatti Ishtar (the wrath of Ishtar) the years of his reign ended. The throne of Elam passed to another." Here ipsukh is from the same verb just mentioned. In Assur. p. 108 there is another account of the same event. "Libbi (the hearts) ili rabi bili-ya (of the great gods my lords) val inukh, val ipsukh (did not let him rest) Sezuzu kabatti bilti-sun, the fiery anger of their divinities [destroyed his reign and ended his years. The throne of Elam passed to another"].

The adjective Sezuzu 'fiery' (usually written) from the verb combussit in the S conjugation, is elsewhere an epithet of lightning, thunderbolts, &c.

The next example is very different. It seems to be some advice to the students. I take it from the photograph of tablet 143 (or 112 a). Aggu libba-kun linukha! may it calm the anger of your minds! lippashra kabatta-kun, may it reconcile your hearts! Written Lippashra is the optative mood of the Rabbinic verb to pacify or reconcile, see Sch. 1498. Observe how constantly the words Lib (the mind) and Kabat (the heart) accompany each other. So also in the Vocabulary (2 R 36, 53) Libbu, and Kabattu stand next but one to each other.

III. Kabat often means the Heart, viewed as the seat of Intelligence. Bellino l. 42 "Then I Sennacherib king of Assyria, by command of the Gods, to complete this great work in uzni-ya
ibsi-ma, kabatti uplam-ma, resolved in my mind, and brought my heart to it.”—More fully given in the Bull inscriptions 3 R 13, 22. B.M. 41, 25. B.M. 60, 27 where among other things, he says “in mirish kubatti-ya (in the skilfulness of my heart) I made figures of bronze, and finished them artistically.”—Mirish comes I think from the root solers, astatus (Schindler p. 660).

IV. Prayers for the king are very frequent. Thus in 2 R 36, 24 As khiga siri, khut libbi, namar kabatti, salmish, &c. “with sound limbs, cheerful mind, and bright heart, may he walk in perfection before thee!” Observe, the three adjectives stand before their substantives.

In Esar vi, 55 the sacred stone bulls and lions are called “the guardians of my royal treasures, and the gladdeners of my heart, mukhadli kabatti-ya. The same text is found in 3 R 16 col. vi, 12.

V. The form Kubat occurs in Assur. p. 153, where the king says the gods have adorned kubat-su ‘his heart’ in kitti u misari ‘with good faith and justice.’ Therefore he received without suspicion the ambassadors of his faithless brother and loaded them with honours.

VI. The form Gabat occurs in Assur. p. 118, in the account of the illness of Tiumman inflicted on him by the anger of the gods. “His lips were swollen, his eyes grew dim, and gabat-zu (his liver) issakin us libbi-sha (was inflamed in its interior).”

On the other hand the adjective kabittu (much : many : numerous) always requires to be preceded by a substantive. It is generally written with the syllable Bit, sometimes though rarely with Bi-it, but never with Bat. Example: Shallatu kabittu ana kireb Assur-ki ashlula “much plunder to Assyria I carried away,” Botta 147, 12.

I turn now to the verb Kubat or Kabad, to have in the heart : to plot or meditate : of which I will give several examples:

1. Opp. Khors. l. 112 “The king of Commagene, a Syrian heretic, not worshipping the gods, kapidu sinieti (plotting rebellion)”
dabibu zalulti (meditating treason). Written Ḫaṣṣu Kapidu.

2. Assur. 164 “The people who had plotted (usakpidu) along with my rebellious brother.” Written Ḫaṣṣu Ḫaṣṣu Kapidu.

3. Assur. 156 Ikbut limut, he devised evil.

4. Same page, Ikbudu limuttu, they devised evil.

But when the verb kabat is joined to libba as in the phrase ikbud libba-su, it is doubtful whether we ought to translate “he devised in his heart” or “he hardened his heart” i.e., “obstinately resolved” (not to pay tribute, or the like). This would be the Hebrew יָדְעַה בְּנֵי פֶרַע ‘the heart of Pharaoh was hardened.’ It is to be observed however that Hebraists refer יָדְעַה בְּנֵי jecur and יָדְעַה בְּנֵי gravis to the same root. The Assyrian usage confirms this, for it seems to intermix the meanings.

501. Issu. Ḫaṣṣu New.

We read in F 25 of R plate 7 Sha bit-zu labiru inakkaru, issu ibannu, “those who had pulled down their old houses and built new ones.” In 2 R 46, 11 there is mention of a ship which is Ḫaṣṣu or old, and of one which is Ḫaṣṣu or new. The Assyrian translation of these terms is Ḫaṣṣu labirtu ‘old’ and Ḫaṣṣu issitu ‘new.’

502. Issut. Ḫaṣṣu Newness. A word of very frequent occurrence.

Bellino l. 20. Nagu suatu ana issuti azbat, ‘that city I built again.’

503. Issish. Ḫaṣṣu Newly. Occurs very frequently.

Phill. ii, 41. The temple of Tara to the Sun and Moon my lords newly I built (issish ebos). The Sun and Moon are Ḫaṣṣu Ḫaṣṣu.

This adverb is also spelt Ḫaṣṣu Ḫaṣṣu ex. gr. Assipar(? ramani-su issish ibannu “he built it newly, according to his own plan(? )” where issish is rendered in Accadian by Ḫaṣṣu Ḫaṣṣu.
I do not think it has been observed by students, that adverbs are formed in the Accadian language by adding \textit{ka}. Of this I have collected numerous examples.

504. Bilut. \textit{ka} Lordship. Sovereignty. \textit{sha bilut Sumir u Akkad ramana's stirra}, who the government of Sumir and Akkad had turned to himself. Sen. T. iv. 36. I give this example on account of the unusual spelling. Norris (dict., p. 147 l. 5) first pointed out that \textit{ka} has lost for one of its values. See another proof of the same in the next article \textit{Ilut}.

505. Ilut. \textit{ka} Divinity. The word is very common but I have only once met with it thus written. \textit{Ilut-ka} 'thy divinity.' The Accadian version agrees.

506. Padi. \textit{ka} Sceptre (see No. 435). As this is an important word I will give another example, taken from one of the tablets. "O Father, creator of gods and men....... Proclaimer of my Sovereignty! Giver of my sceptre!..........."

The original ha-\textit{Nabu surru}, \textit{natan padi} (\textit{ka} \textit{padi}). The final \textit{i} is the pronoun, for the Accadian version adds \textit{mu} (my) in both instances.

The spelling \textit{Pada} is also found, \textit{ex gr.} "The gods of heaven and earth exalted his sceptre over the races of men," \textit{shurudu pada-su il kissat niri}. (Observe the preposition \textit{II}, written \textit{ka}).

507. Kakku. A Sword (see No. 416). I will add some more examples of this word. It is written \textit{ka} \textit{kakku} in the Babylonian inscriptions.

1. Neriglissar l. 13 "Nebo gave him the sceptre of justice, and the god (.....) \textit{gaburu ili} (greatest of the gods) \textit{iddim-su kakku-su} (gave him his sword)."

2. E. I. H. iv. 50. I built a temple to the god (.....) who is the breaker of the sword of my enemies \textit{musabir kakku nakiri-ya}. But it is written \textit{ka} \textit{kakku} in Assyrian inscriptions.

1. 2 R 19, \textit{Kakku sha bulukhti milammi-su} 'his sword of awful brightness' rendered in Accadian by \textit{ka} \textit{immini ani}.

2. Same plate L 63, the Accadian \textit{ka} \textit{immini ani}.
is translated Kakku kalbu sha Anu 'the great sword of Anu.' There is another example in same plate l. 61.

508. Maskanati. Nets. Bulthu II in libbi-su maskanati arba, 'two of them (eagles) I caught alive in Nets.' 3 R 4 No. 4 l. 40. I think this may be the same as the Heb. maskat a Web, from plexuit, texuit: 'to weave a web, or net.' The word is found in Judges xvi, 13 (story of Samson).

509. a City. This is the most usual sign for 'City.' It was sometimes pronounced Ar (Heb. urbs, oppidum), but more often Alu: a word peculiar to the Assyrians (see No. 495). In consequence of this, it has a double value when used as a mere phonetic syllable. It generally sounds Ar, of which many examples occur, but sometimes, though much more rarely, it sounds Ala. Compare Assur. p. 61 with p. 69. The land of Tabal is written in one Tapala, in the other showing that was familiarly pronounced Ala.

Alussu (his city). Ituru alussun, (the gods) returned to their cities. Opp. Khors.

Norris p. 554 and p. 577 thinks the plural is alan, in which I agree with him, for I find alani in the photograph of tablet 133. Speaking of fine marbles, alabaster, &c. Alani isallal sunuti "he will plunder them from the cities." Here alani is rendered which proves the meaning. For isallal, spelt in the same manner, see the art. shallal, No. 461. The barbarous custom of pulling down fine buildings in order to build new ones is here alluded to.

Alan (Cities) in E. I. H. vii, 31 Aramu bana alan-sun "I raised high the building of their cities."

510. Salim. Peace. A remarkable spelling of this word is found on the Omen tablet 3 R 59, 47. "If the Sun and Moon, &c. &c. there will be Peace among nations" Salim kissati.

511. Sadirati. Hunter's Nets. From the Heb. to hunt (wild animals): to lay nets for (birds and
fishes) whence ρτειασ venatio: venator. “Great numbers of wild animals he caught in nets, or hunter's toils,” as sadirati utismikk. R 28, 20.

512. Urbarra. (See No. 469). That this was some great wild beast is evident from R 28, 23 where a very early monarch, Ashurnakhbal, pursues it in the chase. If not a tiger I think it is a panther or great leopard. In 2 R 49, 41 the constellations Urmak and Urbarra stand next each other.

513. Gubbani. ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ Lakes, Pools, or Ponds. Heb. ρτειασ palus, piscina, cisterna.

As eli gubbani sha mie attadi usmanni, “over against pools of water I pitched my camp.” (This was preparatory to crossing an arid desert). Assur. p. 269.

514. Isirtu. ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ Straight. Hebrew יושע rectus. Assur. 235 Kharran isirtu ullus libbi tazbata ana Bit-Anna, “she took the straight road to the temple of Anna, with a joyful heart.”

515. Makhiri. ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ Commerce. Agrees exactly with the Hebrew יושע to buy or sell.

Assur. 275 “They sold a camel for half a shekel of silver in the street of Commerce (or of the Merchants)” — — — — — — — ————. ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ — — — — — — — ———— — — — — — — — ———— — — — — — — — ———— as …….. καρπι isammu as bab makhiri. And a few lines after, imdanakharu gammali u amilutu ‘they bartered camels and men’ [prisoners of war]. Imdanakharu ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ ρτειασ is the Tan conjugation of the verb Makhar to barter.

But the verb Makhar to receive, or store up, has also the same tense, of which the following is an example. Bellino I. 39. “Former kings built a treasure-house at Nineveh, and every year without fail their tributes, received from the four regions, they stored up within it,” imdanakharu kirēb-su.
